subject: Re:Re: thoughts on fail(); in generated tests
msgSnippet: JBR, thanks for your response. I agree with you, that thinking about a test before implementing the according part of the application is very important. I
messageBody:
JBR,

thanks for your response. I agree with you, that thinking
about a test before implementing the according part of
the application is very important.

I understand you refuse to write a compilable but hollow
method of an application method before you write the test.
(This would make the use of a test stub generator impossible.)

There I don't agree. I like the documentation aspect of code
related tests. This kind of tests enable me to look at a test
in order to understand the intention of an application method.
This is very important to me. JUnitDoclet is helping me to
keep application structure and test structure in sync, which
is essential there. Still I can _implement_ the test method
before I _implement_ the application method.

I believe the core idea of "test before code" is
possible with _regenerating_ tools like JUnitDoclet.
It just requires some self control.

After all, this is not a major dissagreement. If there
wouldn't be that documenting aspect of tests...

Regards,

Steffen Gemkow
